The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The California Unemployment Insurance Code permits community college districts to enroll in the California State Disability Insurance Program for select employee groups who are not covered by other sources of disability insurance.  One of these groups cited in the code are the temporary part time faculty of a community college district.  The Executive Director, San Jose/Evergreen Faculty Association, AFT 6157 representing the interest of the adjunct faculty contacted the Vice Chancellor, Human Resources to request that AFT hold a secret ballot election of all temporary adjunct faculty in Fall 2011 to determine if a majority of those voting would want to be covered by State Disability Insurance.  The election was open from December 5, 2011 through December 12, 2011.  The results were 64% of those voting in favor of implementing State Disability Insurance.  The full cost of the State Disability Insurance is paid by the employee through payroll deduction.  The cost to the employee is 1.0% of wages up to maximum earnings of $  95,585    per year for 2012.   In accordance with the process to apply for acceptance in the program to the Employment Development Department, the governing board must pass a resolution authorizing the application.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve resolution No. 011012-2 in order for the District to apply to the California Employment Development Department for acceptance of all temporary part time faculty in the employee-paid State Disability Insurance Program.

items.item_details:
Recently the District Office boiler system, a single boiler, required repairs due to leaks. Upon further inspection it was determined the corrosion to the boiler was beyond repair and required immediate replacement.  To temporarily remedy the problem of the District Office running cold, portable space heaters were distributed by the Maintenance Department throughout the District Office. This action resulted in overloaded circuit breakers. Because of this situation, the District did not seek formal bids as installation of a new boiler would be severely delayed and expose staff and the District to dangers of life and property. 
	 
Attached are multiple bids that were requested informally from various vendors. The District invoked California Public Contract Code Section 20654, which states that “In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to any facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing college classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools… make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids.”  The District received approval from Dr. Charles Weis, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools.
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve and award the contract to Thermal Mechanical, Inc. in the amount of $42,876.00 for the emergency replacement of the District Office boiler system “without advertising for or inviting bids” “to avoid the danger of life or property.”

items.item_details:
On September 27, the Board received a presentation on SJECCD’s redistricting process from Thomas Griffin from the Griffin Law Offices.  Dr. Griffin gave a presentation on the 2010 Census data and discussed its impact on SJECCD current district boundaries. Dr. Griffin provided a demographic report of each trustee area. He reviewed the 1 Person 1 Vote Rule, principles of the Voting Rights Act and those portions of the Education Code requiring that all school districts redraw their trustee areas after the federal census. Dr. Griffin also introduced the principle of 1% variance among contiguous trustee areas.  In other words, that we draw district boundaries that distribute the population in our service area within 1% of the ideal population.
 Since that first presentation the Board of Trustees has reviewed several presentations that: 
Reviewed principles established by the Board of Trustees during the last redistricting effort in 2001 and integrate these same principles in the proposed options to be brought back to the Board (the overarching concern here is not to disadvantage minority communities and to support the election of a diverse board).
Included GPS maps of proposed options that include major traffic arteries to make it easier to determine when a trustee area begins and ends and to compare and contrast with the current boundaries.
Presented clear timelines between the next presentation (first formal public hearing) and the end of the process.
Discussed the implementation of outreach efforts to inform district constituents (voters) of the process underway at SJECCD including opportunities for public input.
Conducted a public hearing and received public input.
Resulted in further adjustments to the preferred redistricting option boundaries.
This item presents an overview of the top three most viable options resulting from the review conducted thus far.  In addition this time proposes a recommended option for final board adoption that responds to the concerns raised during the December 13, 2011 public hearing session on the topic.  This option complies with all of the six principles established by the Board of Trustees, and responds to public hearing input by addressing the following: 
1.  Maximizing cohesiveness of school district boundaries
2.  Producing trustee boundaries that are more closely aligned with the current boundary lines
3.  Maximizing majority/minority voting areas
4.  Protecting continuity of community of interest groupings
	 
Note:  All information referenced above may be accessed on the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Website through the following link:
 http://www.sjeccd.edu/aboutus/board/Pages/Redistrict.aspx
	 
 Attachments
Redistricting Trustee Area Boundary Adjustment SJECCD  January 10, 2012 Presentation
Plan 5 (Modified Nakamura Plan 4 and Recommended Option)

Accreditation Recommendation 5 (Board Governance) addressed the need for systematic review and revision of board policies to ensure they are “up to date.” The Commission was clear that this process should “include a robust ethics policy that establishes steps to be taken should a board member violate the policy.” BP 2715 Code of Ethics/Standards of Practice was approved by the Board of Trustees on January 10, 2006. However, this policy was deficient by Commission standards in that it did not contain language regarding a breach in ethics by one or more Board members. 
	 
The attached policy is presented for a first reading by the Board. Page one was Board approved on January 10, 2006, however, two sentences have been added to note the Board’s priority for “student success” (see italicized text)Page two (noted with draft watermark) is draft language reviewed by District Council and their respective constituent groups. District Council yields page two to the Board for language changes after which they will take back to their respective constituent groups and to District Council for review.

In November 2011 the Board approved an update to the Evergreen Valley College Master Plan that identified the remodel and rehabilitation of the existing Central Utility Plant at the College.  In keeping with the updated Master Plan, the District issued a Request for Proposal for Professional Design Services.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to 12 businesses which qualify as one of the following: Minority Business Enterprise, Woman Owned Business Enterprise, Disabled Veterans Business Enterprise, or Small Business Enterprise.
	 
The Request for Proposal (RFP) process required a detailed Qualifications submittal and a separate envelope for each respondent’s fee proposal (a lump sum programming fee and a percentage of construction cost for all other services).  In response to the District’s RFP, nine (9) proposals were received on November 29, 2011.  Responding firms were:
NTD Architecture
LPA, Inc.
Architecture / vbn*
DSK Architects
BFGC-IBI Group
Sugimura Finney Architects
WLC Architects
Salas O’Brien Engineers
Aedis Architecture & Planning*
(*Denotes Minority Business Enterprise, Woman Owned Business Enterprise, Disabled Veterans Business Enterprise, or Small Business Enterprise )
	 
A panel comprised of District, College and Gilbane personnel reviewed each RFP response and identified three firms for further interview.  These interviews were held December 7, 2011.  After interviews, the panel reconvened and determined that all three firms should have their fee proposal envelopes opened.  Based on the results of the fees received, the firms were ranked as follows:
	 
        1. Aedis Architecture & Planning
        2. Architecture / vbn
        3. NTD Architecture
	 
Contract negotiations were completed with Aedis and final terms agreed with District legal counsel.  The contract includes a Master Agreement for design services and a Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) that identifies the specific scope of the Central Plant contract.
	 
	 
Attachments:
A/E RFQ Review Summary
Project Authorization Amendment #1
Design Professional Master Agreement
Shortlist Interview Summary 
RFQ responses and other documentation available upon request to Gilbane.

An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District on November 2, 2010 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $268,000,000 (the “Authorization”).  The District now desires to issue up to $100,000,000 of general obligation bonds in two series of bonds (collectively, the “Bonds”).
	 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Bonds.  The Resolution approves the form of Bond Purchase Contract, and the forms of the Preliminary Official Statements described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution authorizes the issuance of two series of bonds, in an aggregate maximum principal amount of $100,000,000.  The first series of bonds are intended to finance capital projects, while the second series of bonds are intended to fund a technology/deferred maintenance endowment, as approved by the voters.  Section 3 of the Resolution authorizes the Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale and the maximum underwriter’s discount (0.8%) with respect to the Bonds.  The Resolution authorizes the Chancellor and Vice Chancellor, Administrative Services to execute any and all documents which are necessary in order to issue the Bonds.  No further Board action will be required. 
	 
(b)        Form of Bond Purchase Contracts.  Pursuant to the Bond Purchase Contracts relating to each series of Bonds, Piper Jaffray & Co. and RBC Capital Markets, LLC, will agree to buy the Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Bonds, the final execution copy of the Bond Purchase Contracts will be prepared following these forms.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statements (each, a “POS”) is the offering document describing the Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to among other things (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Bonds (the tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of each POS.

items.item_details: Chancellor Cepeda and Interim Vice Chancellor Smith will provide a budget update.
Chancellor Cepeda will provide a legislative update.

The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District has a long and proud history centered on issues of “Social Justice” that are student focused.  As an example, this District has led the State in advocating and supporting legislation, policies and practices in support of nonresident students in their quest for higher education. 
	 
In 2007, the trustees and senior administration supported the implementation of a “fee deferral promise” to be tendered to nonresident students.  Under this plan, both college presidents and the SJECCD Foundation were given the charge to raise private funds to pay the enrollment fees for AB540 students who required financial assistance.  It is important to note two basic points:
 The “Fee Deferral Promise” was an administrative action, that while supported by the board, was not formally documented as board action.
Due to administrative turnover, fundraising efforts to cover costs were planned but not fully solidified.
By spring 2009, both colleges recognized the fiscal impracticality of maintaining an internal “fee deferral promise” and initiated plans to look for alternative ways to support nonresident students. In summer 2010, Chancellor Cepeda issued a new directive regarding the “fee deferral promise” to both colleges which include the following:  
We would honor the “promise” made to students the previous academic years (i.e. 2007/2008 -2009/2010).
Beginning with fall 2010, all AB540 students would be informed of their responsibility to pay enrollment fees.
The colleges were charged with the identification of student support strategies to continue to support these students (i.e. payment plans, identification of applicable private funds, book loans etc.)
Establishment of a district wide planning and coordinating team to address the fiscal liability incurred to date: namely, strategies for raising the necessary private funds to cover costs. 
In this presentation, Chancellor Cepeda will address the district impact associated with the former ‘fee deferral promise,” AB540 fee liability in contrast to the overall receivable debt, current fundraising efforts to make good on the “fee deferral promise” and new state legislation which will ease financial hardship for AB540 students.
